donald trump: I do n't think taxpayers should be paying to send Donald Trump's kids to college.

emotionalLines: Our country deserves no less, because all of the other issues we want to deal with depend upon us being secure and strong.
Well, John, I think that we have to look at ISIS as the leading threat of an international terror network.

And then, with the revolution against Assad -- and I did early on say we needed to try to find a way to train and equip moderates very early so that we would have a better idea of how to deal with Assad because I thought there would be extremist groups filling the vacuum.
I have said the invasion of Iraq was a mistake.
The increasing globalization without any real safety valve for people to have a better life.

Well, I think -- I think that is very unfair to a few you mentioned, most particularly Jordan, which has put a lot on the line for the United States, has also taken in hundreds of thousands of refugees from Syria, and has been, therefore, subjected to threats and attacks by extremists themselves.

And it is imperative that we do more not only to help our friends and partners protect themselves and protect our own homeland, but also to work to try to deal with this arc of instability, which does have a lot of impact on what happens in a country like Libya.
Well, I think it's perfectly fair to say that we invested quite a bit in development aid.
I do n't think we're at war with all Muslims.
We are at war with violent extremism.

I plead that it's very difficult when you deal with ISIS and organizations like that whose behavior is so barbaric and so vicious that it does n't seem to have any purpose other than lust for killing and power and that's very difficult to put ourselves in the other shoe.
We passed it after 9/11.
I would like to see it updated.
So there's a lot of work we need to do and I want to be sure what's called the AUMF, has the authority that is needed going forward.
So we've got to look at the full range and then come to some smart decisions about having more streamlined and focused approach.
And I will pay for it by, yes, taxing the wealthy more, closing corporate loopholes, deductions, and other kinds of favorable treatment.
For example, it is outrageous that we do n't have an opportunity for Medicare to negotiate for lower prices.
But I think it's important to understand there's a significant difference that I have with Senator Sanders about how best to provide quality, affordable health care for everyone.

And my reading of the law and the Constitution convinces me that the President has the authority that he is attempting to exercise with respect to dreamers and their parents, because I think all of us on this stage agree that we need comprehensive immigration reform with a path to citizenship.

donald trump: The fact of the matter is -- and let's say it in our debate, because you'll never hear this from that immigration-bashing carnival barker, Donald Trump, the truth of the matter is...

emotionalLines: Parents, and sons, and daughters and family members, and as our hearts go out to them and as our prayers go out to them, we must remember this, that this is n't the new face of conflict and warfare, not in the 20th century but the new face of conflict and warfare in the 21st century.
And ISIS, make no mistake about it, is an evil in this world.
We need to be much more far thinking in this new 21st century era of -- of nation state failures and conflict.

These are American soldiers and we fail them when we fail to take into account what happens the day after a dictator falls and when we fail to act with a whole of government approach with sustainable development, diplomacy, and our economic power in alignment with our principles.

And we are going to be able to defeat ISIS on the ground there, as well as in this world, because of the Muslim Americans in our country and throughout the world who understand that this brutal and barbaric group is perverting the name of a great world religion.
This is a new era of conflict where traditional ways of huge standing armies are not as -- serve our purposes as well as special ops, better intelligence and being more proactive.
That's what I understand is the request from the international..
I would want us to take our place among the nations of the world to alleviate this sort of death and the specter we saw of little kids' bodies washing up on a beach.
That's right.

I believe that we pay for many of the things that we need to do again as a nation, investing in the skills of our people, our infrastructure, and research and development and also climate change by the elimination of one big entitlement that we can no longer afford as a people, and that is the entitlement that many of our super wealthiest citizens feel they are entitled to pay -- namely, a much lower income tax rate and a lower tax rate on capital gains.
That's right.

And in talking to a lot of our neighbors who are in that super wealthy, millionaire and billionaire category, a great numbers of them love their country enough to do more again in order to create more opportunity for America's middle class.
All right, Nancy, I really wish you'd come back to me on this on this one, John..
Because we have found a way to reduce hospital costs, so whenever we come..
[ applause ] The truth of the matter is, net immigration from Mexico last year was zero.
And so, look, the way that -- a stronger middle class is actually the source of economic growth.
The fact of the matter is, the more our people earn, the more money they spend, and the more our whole economy grows.

hillary clinton: Why do -- why, over her political career has Wall Street been a major -- the major campaign contributor to Hillary Clinton?
I was sick and tired of Hillary Clinton's e-mail.
But after I said that, we're not hearing so much about Hillary Clinton's e-mails.What

emotionalLines: And then on top of that, we've got a corrupt campaign finance system in which millionaires and billionaires are pouring huge sums of money into super PACS heavily influencing the political process.

And if we do not get our act together and listen to what the scientists say, you're going to see countries all over the world -- this is what the CIA says -- they're going to be struggling over limited amounts of water, limited amounts of land to grow their crops ask you're going to see all kinds of international conflict.
I think that was one of the worst foreign policy blunders in the more than history of the United States.
I think we have a disagreement, and the disagreement is that not only did I vote against the war in Iraq.
... And that I am not a great fan of regime change.
We should be supportive of that effort.
The 500,000 who came home with PTSD, and traumatic brain injury.
And that this world, with American leadership, can and must come together to destroy them.

So, in terms of refugees, I believe that the United States has the moral responsibility with Europe, with Gulf countries like Saudi Arabia to make sure that when people leave countries like Afghanistan and Syria with nothing more than the clothing on their back that, of course, we reach out.
Trillions of dollars have gone from the middle class and working families to the top one-tenth of one percent who have doubled the percentage of wealth they now own.
[ applause ] But -- but we are going to end the absurdity, as Warren Buffet often remind us.
There has to be real tax reform, and the wealthiest and large corporations will pay when I'm president.

[ applause ] And also -- also, what we should be clear about is we end up spending -- and I think the secretary knows this -- far more per capita on health care than any other major country, and our outcomes, health care outcomes are not necessarily that good.
You know, no public policy does n't have, in some cases, negative consequences.

This is what I think -- this is what many economists believe that one of the reasons that real unemployment in this country is 10 percent, one of the reasons that African American youth unemployment and underemployment is 51 percent is the average worker in America does n't have any disposable income.
Let me just...
You're seeing cities like San Francisco, cities like Los Angeles doing it, and they are doing it well and workers are able to have more disposable income.
Not good enough. [ applause ] Here's the story.

I have never heard a candidate never, who has received huge amounts of money from oil, from coal, from Wall Street, from the military industrial complex, not one candidate say, oh, these campaign contributions will not influence me.
No, I have not.
